snippet: Far fewer refugees were discovered on a mountain in Iraq, a U.S. team reported, and they were no longer either starving or stranded.
abstract: United States pulls back on plans to use ground troops to rescue Yazidis stranded on Mount Sinjar in Iraq after US officials report that there are only between 4,000 to 5,000 civilians remaining on the mountain, significantly fewer than the tens of thousands thought to have been there, and says they are no longer starving or stranded.

byline.original: By HELENE COOPER, MICHAEL D. SHEAR and ROD NORDLAND
byline.contributor: Helene Cooper reported from Washington; Michael D. Shear from Egartown, Mass.; and Rod Nordland from Istanbul. Mark Mazzetti contributed reporting from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Far fewer refugees were discovered on a mountain in Iraq, a U.S. team reported, and they were no longer either starving or stranded.

headline.main: U.S. Pulls Back on Plans for a Mountain Rescue
headline.print_headline: U.S. Pulls Back on Plans for a Mountain Rescue
